Overview

Congenital dermal melanocytosis (CDM) is a benign pigmented condition that manifests at birth as flat, blue-gray patches classically located on the sacrum or buttocks.  No treatment is required because the lesions fade in early childhood.  However, differentiation of CDM from bruising (ie, nonaccidental trauma) is required.

Pathogenesis



CDM is a benign, pigmented condition caused by the delayed disappearance of melanocytes within the dermis.  In utero, melanocytes normally migrate from the neural crest to the epidermis through the dermis.  CDM is likely related to arrested melanocyte migration within the dermis, resulting in melanin production in this deeper layer of skin and the characteristic blue-gray color.  This likely explains the higher incidence in patients with darker skin tones; CDM was formerly referred to as "mongolian spots."



The trapped dermal melanocytes are contained within a fibrous sheath, which expands and deteriorates over time, resulting in fading and resolution of the lesion over time.

Clinical presentation



CDM lesions are asymptomatic, flat, blue-gray patches that are present at birth.  Examination shows patches that are nontender, round or irregularly shaped (sometimes >10 cm in diameter (

image 1
)), and often poorly circumscribed.  They are characteristically located over the sacrum and buttocks but may be located on the anterior trunk or extremities; facial involvement is not typical (
image 2
).

Differential diagnosis



  • Ecchymoses (
    image 3
    ):  Unexplained bruising in a child is concerning for a bleeding disorder or nonaccidental trauma.  Features distinguishing bruising from lesions of CDM include variability in color (as opposed to uniformity) and acute onset (rather than since birth); traumatic bruising is also tender.
  • Caf√© au lait spots (
    figure 1
    ):  These lesions are flat and uniformly hyperpigmented (brown) with distinct margins.
  • Congenital melanocytic nevi (
    image 4
    ):  These raised, hyperpigmented lesions often have an increased density of overlying dark, coarse hairs (hypertrichosis).
  • Infantile hemangiomas (
    image 5
    ):  Superficial hemangiomas are the most common type and present as nontender, bright red, sharply demarcated nodules/plaques; at birth, they are classically absent or manifest as a telangiectasia precursor lesion.  Deep hemangiomas develop in the subcutaneous tissue and often have a faint bluish hue but are not present at birth, are usually associated with a superficial (ie, bright red) component, and grow during early infancy into raised nodules.

Diagnosis



CDM is diagnosed clinically based on its characteristic appearance (eg, flat, blue-gray patch).  The diagnosis is supported when the parents and/or medical records indicate that lesions have been present since birth.



Notably, CDM in its classic sacral location is not a cutaneous marker for an occult spinal dysraphism (such as a lipoma, hair tuft, hemangioma, or atypical sacral dimple) and therefore does not warrant imaging.

Management and prognosis



Management is reassurance alone because CDM is benign and usually fades spontaneously by age 5.  However, examination findings should be documented at every visit because the patches can be mistaken for bruises, especially when in a less common location (eg, extremities, chest).

Summary



Congenital dermal melanocytosis presents as flat, blue-gray patches, most commonly on the sacrum and buttocks in infants.  The diagnosis is clinical, and management includes reassurance and documentation to avoid misdiagnosis (eg, bruising).  The lesions usually fade spontaneously during early childhood.
